# Results {#results}

## CX3CL1/CX3CR1 signaling in the basolateral nucleus of the amygdala

Considering CX3CR1 implication in anxiety as well as its relatively high expression in the amygdala, the neurophysiological consequences, such as neuronal activity, synaptic transmission, and long-term potentiation, were explored. <!-- modulation of the electrical properties in BLA neurons // To explore how CX3CL1 impacts electrophysiological features in the BLA, -->

### CX3CR1 activation reduces the excitability of principal neurons in the rat BLA

<!-- Considering presented above immunohistochemical findings that CX3CL1 showed higher expression of CX3CL1 in the BLA under basal conditions, it might modulate neuronal activity and excitability in this area. -->
First, the intrinsic firing properties of principal cells, the most numerous neurons in the BLA,  were assessed through whole-cell patch-clamp recordings, evoking action potentials in response to somatic current injection.
<!-- nie wiem czy poruszyć
Mixed design ANOVA revealed that principal cells fired significantly less after CX3CL1 application (group × current steps intensity interaction: F(1.973,53.279)=19.648, P<0.001, Greenhouse–Geisser correction) (Figure 4d). -->

The analysis revealed that following CX3CL1 treatment, the action potential's threshold was significantly more depolarized, as compared to baseline (from `r round(BLA_df_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'CX3CL1(2nM)' & Condition == "baseline") %>% ungroup() %>% summarize(mean(Treshold1_all)), digits = 2)` `r knitr::asis_output("\U00B1")` `r round(BLA_df_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'CX3CL1(2nM)' & Condition == "baseline") %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::summarize(x = sd(Treshold1_all), count = n()) %>% dplyr::summarize(x/sqrt(count)), digits = 2)` to `r round(BLA_df_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'CX3CL1(2nM)' & Condition == "CX3CL1") %>% ungroup() %>% summarize(mean(Treshold1_all)), digits = 2)` `r knitr::asis_output("\U00B1")` `r round(BLA_df_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'CX3CL1(2nM)' & Condition == "CX3CL1") %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::summarize(x = sd(Treshold1_all), count = n()) %>% dplyr::summarize(x/sqrt(count)), digits = 2)` mV, n = `r BLA_df_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'CX3CL1(2nM)') %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::select(Cell) %>% n_distinct()`, N = `r BLA_df_final %>% dplyr::filter(Experiment == 'CX3CL1(2nM)') %>% group_by(Filename_all1) %>% mutate(animals = str_sub(Filename_all1, start = 1, end = 5)) %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::select(animals) %>% n_distinct()`, `r CX3CL1_2nM_BLA_stat_tres`, see Fig. \@ref(fig:CX3CL1BLAexcitabilityfrak)b).
Hence, the higher current injection is needed to induce neuronal firing, suggesting that pyramidal-like neurons may be less excitable in the presence of CX3CL1.
As shown in Fig. \@ref(fig:CX3CL1BLAexcitabilityfrak)d1), the gain (slope) remained unchanged (baseline = `r round(BLA_df_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'CX3CL1(2nM)' & Condition == "baseline") %>% ungroup() %>% summarize(mean(gain)), digits = 2)` `r knitr::asis_output("\U00B1")` `r round(BLA_df_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'CX3CL1(2nM)' & Condition == "baseline") %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::summarize(x = sd(gain), count = n()) %>% dplyr::summarize(x/sqrt(count)), digits = 3)`, CX3CL1(2nM) = `r round(BLA_df_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'CX3CL1(2nM)' & Condition == "CX3CL1") %>% ungroup() %>% summarize(mean(gain)), digits = 2)` `r knitr::asis_output("\U00B1")` `r round(BLA_df_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'CX3CL1(2nM)' & Condition == "CX3CL1") %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::summarize(x = sd(gain), count = n()) %>% dplyr::summarize(x/sqrt(count)), digits = 3)`, see Fig. \@ref(fig:CX3CL1BLAexcitabilityfigall1) and \@ref(fig:CX3CL1BLAexcitabilityfigall2) in the Appendix \@ref(CX3CL1membraneappendix)). <!--figure Appendix-->

Similar effects were observed in higher dose (baseline = `r round(BLA_df_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'CX3CL1(5nM)' & Condition == "baseline") %>% ungroup() %>% summarize(mean(Treshold1_all)), digits = 2)` `r knitr::asis_output("\U00B1")` `r round(BLA_df_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'CX3CL1(5nM)' & Condition == "baseline") %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::summarize(x = sd(Treshold1_all), count = n()) %>% dplyr::summarize(x/sqrt(count)), digits = 2)`, CX3CL1(5nM) = `r round(BLA_df_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'CX3CL1(5nM)' & Condition == "CX3CL1") %>% ungroup() %>% summarize(mean(Treshold1_all)), digits = 2)` `r knitr::asis_output("\U00B1")` `r round(BLA_df_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'CX3CL1(5nM)' & Condition == "CX3CL1") %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::summarize(x = sd(Treshold1_all), count = n()) %>% dplyr::summarize(x/sqrt(count)), digits = 2)` mV, n = `r BLA_df_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'CX3CL1(5nM)') %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::select(Cell) %>% n_distinct()`, N = `r BLA_df_final %>% dplyr::filter(Experiment == 'CX3CL1(5nM)') %>% group_by(Filename_all1) %>% mutate(animals = str_sub(Filename_all1, start = 1, end = 5)) %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::select(animals) %>% n_distinct()`, `r CX3CL1_5nM_BLA_stat_tres`, see Fig. \@ref(fig:CX3CL1BLAexcitabilityfrak)b). <!-- ale czy efekt nie większy dla CX3CL1? MIXED / REPEATED MEASURE ANOVA AND INTERACTION? -->
To confirm whether CX3CL1-induced reduction in the excitability is dependent on CX3CL1 receptor, CX3CR1, the two approaches were used. 
First, before recordings, a subset of slices was incubated with antibodies against CX3CR1 (2ng/ml). <!--jakieć cytowanie które też tak robiło?-->
Under such experimental conditions, the CX3CL1-induced reduction in principal cells' excitability was not statistically significant; however, there still was a proportion of neurons responding with an increased action potential threshold (Fig. \@ref(fig:CX3CL1BLAexcitabilityfrak)b).
Notably, slices used in this study were 300 `r knitr::asis_output("\U03BC")`m thin, and the penetration of antibody was limited (`r knitr::asis_output("\U223C")` 50 `r knitr::asis_output("\U03BC")`m as estimated by analysis of post-recording immunostaining on a subset of slices).<!--albo see i odwołanie do rysunku albo cytowanie Fogarty MJ, Hammond LA, Kanjhan R, Bellingham MC, Noakes PG. A method for the three-dimensional reconstruction of Neurobiotin-filled neurons and the location of their synaptic inputs. Front Neural Circuits 7: 153, 2013. /// Although our neurochemical immunolabeling is limited by antibody penetration, and is therefore confined to subsampling of cell bodies and neuronal arbors that lie within 32um of the surface of the slice, we found an association between sIPSC frequency and neurochemical-->
To this end, another subset of experiments was performed using a pharmacological approach with selected AZD8797 to inhibit CX3CR1.<!-- by antagonist.// For this reason, we selected AZD8797  to  inhibit  CX3CR1  for  investigating  its pharmacological  role  towards  inflammation  during hypertension.  // For this reason, this observation was additionally confirmed using pharmacological inhibition of CX3CR1 receptor, a selective antagonist (AZD8797).--><!-- NIE WIEM CZY TO PISAĆ...Moreover, since 10 `r knitr::asis_output("\U03BC")`M AZD8797 was previously reported to efficiently prevented CX3CL1-induced outcomes, along with its elimination of the observed effect on PCs' excitability, I decided to use this concentration experiments presented in this dissertation.--><!--We decided to use, in all future experiments, 100 nM of CXCL16 since, at this concentration, neuronal cell death was efficiently prevented ...At all the tested concentrations, CXCL16 per se was not toxic (data not shown). --><!-- w tym artykule odwołują się na [] czyli badania gdzie antagonista jest nazwany 18a też są spoko!!!! @karlstrm_2013--><!-- The in vivo IC  50  was  estimated at 2  μ  M (range, 1.5  –  4  μ  M).@ridderstadwollberg_2014  -->
As shown in Fig. \@ref(fig:CX3CL1BLAexcitabilityfrak), AZD8797 prevented the CX3CL1-induced decrease in principal cells' excitability, manifested as an increased action potential threshold, and thereby additionally confirmed CX3CR1 mediation in the observed effect (`r CX3CL1_azdfrak2nM_BLA_stat_tres`, n = `r BLA_df_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'AZD8797 + \nCX3CL1(2nM)') %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::select(Cell) %>% n_distinct()`, N = `r BLA_df_final %>% dplyr::filter(Experiment == 'AZD8797 + \nCX3CL1(2nM)') %>% group_by(Filename_all1) %>% mutate(animals = str_sub(Filename_all1, start = 1, end = 5)) %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::select(animals) %>% n_distinct()`).
<!-- dodatkowa analiza porównująca ANTIBODY AND AZD + CX3CL1 czy napisanie o różnicy w proporcji odpowiadających komórek? -->
Of note, AZD9787 did not affect this parameter when applied alone (Fig. \@ref(fig:CX3CL1BLAexcitabilityadd)a, baseline in DMSO = `r round(BLA_df_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'AZD8797' & Condition == "baseline") %>% ungroup() %>% summarize(mean(Treshold1_all)), digits = 2)` `r knitr::asis_output("\U00B1")` `r round(BLA_df_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'AZD8797' & Condition == "baseline") %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::summarize(x = sd(Treshold1_all), count = n()) %>% dplyr::summarize(x/sqrt(count)), digits = 2)`, AZD8797(10`r knitr::asis_output("\U03BC")`M) = `r round(BLA_df_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'AZD8797' & Condition == "AZD8797") %>% ungroup() %>% summarize(mean(Treshold1_all)), digits = 2)` `r knitr::asis_output("\U00B1")` `r round(BLA_df_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'AZD8797' & Condition == "AZD8797") %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::summarize(x = sd(Treshold1_all), count = n()) %>% dplyr::summarize(x/sqrt(count)), digits = 2)` mV, n = `r BLA_df_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'AZD8797') %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::select(Cell) %>% n_distinct()`, N = `r BLA_df_final %>% dplyr::filter(Experiment == 'AZD8797') %>% group_by(Filename_all1) %>% mutate(animals = str_sub(Filename_all1, start = 1, end = 5)) %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::select(animals) %>% n_distinct()`, `r CX3CL1_azda_BLA_stat_tres`). 

Since it is well-known that the CX3CR1 receptor is mostly expressed on microglia, next, the possible involvement of this type of glial cells in mediating CX3CL1-induced reduction of PCs excitability was investigated.<!-- citations--><!--wcześniej : the protocol to pharmacologically inhibit microglial cells using minocycline on acute brain slices were adapted from other studies. // Since we found that CXCR6 is functionally expressed on microglia (see Fig. 2), we wanted to investigate the possible involvement of microglia in mediating CXCL16-induced neuroprotective effect. For this reason we pretreated hippocampal neuronal cultures with minocycline, a tetracycline-like antibiotic known to inhibit microglia activation, before Glu insult.
-->
For this reason, the slices were pretreated with 100`r knitr::asis_output("\U03BC")`M minocycline, a tetracycline-like antibiotic known to inhibit microglia activation, before and during CX3CL1 application.
As presented in Fig. \@ref(fig:CX3CL1BLAexcitabilityfrak), the inhibition of microglial activity also diminished the CX3CL1-triggered effect on the action potential threshold (`r CX3CL1_minofrak2nM_BLA_stat_tres`).
In contrast, the minocycline applied alone increased the excitability of PCs (baseline = `r round(BLA_df_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'minocycline' & Condition == "baseline") %>% ungroup() %>% summarize(mean(Treshold1_all)), digits = 2)` `r knitr::asis_output("\U00B1")` `r round(BLA_df_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'minocycline' & Condition == "baseline") %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::summarize(x = sd(Treshold1_all), count = n()) %>% dplyr::summarize(x/sqrt(count)), digits = 2)`, minocycline (100`r knitr::asis_output("\U03BC")`M) = `r round(BLA_df_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'minocycline' & Condition == "minocycline") %>% ungroup() %>% summarize(mean(Treshold1_all)), digits = 2)` `r knitr::asis_output("\U00B1")` `r round(BLA_df_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'minocycline' & Condition == "minocycline") %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::summarize(x = sd(Treshold1_all), count = n()) %>% dplyr::summarize(x/sqrt(count)), digits = 2)` mV, n = `r BLA_df_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'minocycline') %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::select(Cell) %>% n_distinct()`, N = `r BLA_df_final %>% dplyr::filter(Experiment == 'minocycline') %>% group_by(Filename_all1) %>% mutate(animals = str_sub(Filename_all1, start = 1, end = 5)) %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::select(animals) %>% n_distinct()`, `r CX3CL1_minoa_BLA_stat_tres`, Fig. \@ref(fig:CX3CL1BLAexcitabilityadd)). 
Thus, this finding highlights the potential importance of microglial functions in regulating the activity of neurons in the BLA. 

Finally, since it is increasingly evident that the activity of principal cells in the BLA is tightly controlled by a heterogeneous group of interneurons (see Introduction \@ref(BLA)), it was investigated whether blocking GABA~A~ and GABA~B~ receptors would eliminate this depressing effect on PCs' firing by CX3CL1.<!-- To isolate AMPA-mediated eEPSCs, picrotoxin (100m) and APV (50m) were added to the bath /// ZMIENIĆ!!!!!!!!! I DODAĆ JACY ANTAGONIŚCI!!!!!!!!! dawki Treatment with both GABA~A~ and GABA~B~ antagonists (picrotoxin, 100 ... and ) ... fully abolished the neuronal response to CX3CL1.--> 
For this reason, recordings were made with additional presence of the picrotoxin (100`r knitr::asis_output("\U03BC")`M) and CGP52432 (10`r knitr::asis_output("\U03BC")`M), respectively.
As expected, the CX3CL1 effect was fully abolished when the GABA~A~ and GABA~B~ receptors were blocked (baseline = `r round(BLA_df_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'picrotoxin + \nCGP52432 + \nCX3CL1(2nM)' & Condition == "baseline") %>% ungroup() %>% summarize(mean(Treshold1_all)), digits = 2)` `r knitr::asis_output("\U00B1")` `r round(BLA_df_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'picrotoxin + \nCGP52432 + \nCX3CL1(2nM)' & Condition == "baseline") %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::summarize(x = sd(Treshold1_all), count = n()) %>% dplyr::summarize(x/sqrt(count)), digits = 2)`, CX3CL1 (2nM) = `r round(BLA_df_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'picrotoxin + \nCGP52432 + \nCX3CL1(2nM)' & Condition == "CX3CL1") %>% ungroup() %>% summarize(mean(Treshold1_all)), digits = 2)` `r knitr::asis_output("\U00B1")` `r round(BLA_df_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'picrotoxin + \nCGP52432 + \nCX3CL1(2nM)' & Condition == "CX3CL1") %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::summarize(x = sd(Treshold1_all), count = n()) %>% dplyr::summarize(x/sqrt(count)), digits = 2)` mV, n = `r BLA_df_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'picrotoxin + \nCGP52432 + \nCX3CL1(2nM)') %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::select(Cell) %>% n_distinct()`, N = `r BLA_df_final %>% dplyr::filter(Experiment == 'picrotoxin + \nCGP52432 + \nCX3CL1(2nM)') %>% group_by(Filename_all1) %>% mutate(animals = str_sub(Filename_all1, start = 1, end = 5)) %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::select(animals) %>% n_distinct()`, `r CX3CL1_gabafrak2nM_BLA_stat_tres`, Fig. \@ref(fig:CX3CL1BLAexcitabilityfrak)b).
Thus, these data suggest that CX3CL1 reduced principal cells' firing *via* CX3CR1-, microglia-, and interneuron-dependent manner.<!-- cooperate?-->

Having established a significant CX3CL1-modulated suppression of principal cells’ firing, the main group of glutamatergic neurons in the BLA, actions of CX3CL1 on the excitatory transmission in this area was measured.<!--lepsze druga część zdania?-->
Spontaneous excitatory postsynaptic currents (sEPSCs) were recorded *via* whole-cell patch-clamp recordings (held at −70 mV). 
<!--The representative traces of sEPSCs in the absence (referred to as control hereafter) or presence of harmine (10μM) (referred to as harmine) were shown in supplemental Fig. S1(A). -->
All measured parameters of excitatory synaptic transmission before and after  the application of CX3CL1, AZD8797, and minocycline are described in detail in Appendix \@ref(CX3CL1sEPSCappendix), summarized in the Table <!-- --> and illustrated in Fig. \@ref(fig:CX3CL1BLAsEPSCfigall).
Compared to the control, CX3CL1 in both measured concentration (2nM and 5nM) had a negligible effect on the median value of the amplitude, frequency, and kinetics of sEPSCs.
However, although statistically not significant, a proportion of neurons (`r knitr::asis_output("\U223C")` 50%) reacted with a decreased frequency of excitatory synaptic currents (Fig. \@ref(fig:CX3CL1BLAsEPSC)a).<!-- CX3CL1 was shown to have negligible effect on the frequency of excitatory synaptic currents./// In contrast to inhibitory synaptic transmission, compared to baseline, CX3CL1 had negligible effect on the mean value of sEPSC amplitude and frequency, which was further described in the Appendix (see: \@ref(CX3CL1sEPSCappendix)). // found that although a partial reduction between NMDA and NMDA/CX3CL1 treated cells was observed, it was not statistical significant
-->

Furthermore, similar to previous findings, in addition to upregulated excitability, minocycline alone also altered sEPSC kinetics by increasing both their rise time from `r round(BLA_sEPSC_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'minocycline' & Condition == "baseline") %>% ungroup() %>% summarize(mean(median_RiseTime)), digits = 2)` `r knitr::asis_output("\U00B1")` `r round(BLA_sEPSC_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'minocycline' & Condition == "baseline") %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::summarize(x = sd(median_RiseTime), count = n()) %>% dplyr::summarize(x/sqrt(count)), digits = 2)` to `r round(BLA_sEPSC_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'minocycline' & Condition == "minocycline") %>% ungroup() %>% summarize(mean(median_RiseTime)), digits = 2)` `r knitr::asis_output("\U00B1")` `r round(BLA_sEPSC_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'minocycline' & Condition == "minocycline") %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::summarize(x = sd(median_RiseTime), count = n()) %>% dplyr::summarize(x/sqrt(count)), digits = 2)` ms, n = `r BLA_sEPSC_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'minocycline') %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::select(Cell) %>% n_distinct()`, N = `r BLA_sEPSC_final %>% dplyr::filter(Experiment == 'minocycline') %>% group_by(Filename) %>% mutate(animals = str_sub(Filename, start = 1, end = 5)) %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::select(animals) %>% n_distinct()`, `r CX3CL1_sEPSC_mino_BLA_stat_sEPSC_rt`) and 
decay time from `r round(BLA_sEPSC_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'minocycline' & Condition == "baseline") %>% ungroup() %>% summarize(mean(median_DecayTau)), digits = 2)` `r knitr::asis_output("\U00B1")` `r round(BLA_sEPSC_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'minocycline' & Condition == "baseline") %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::summarize(x = sd(median_DecayTau), count = n()) %>% dplyr::summarize(x/sqrt(count)), digits = 2)` to `r round(BLA_sEPSC_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'minocycline' & Condition == "minocycline") %>% ungroup() %>% summarize(mean(median_DecayTau)), digits = 2)` `r knitr::asis_output("\U00B1")` `r round(BLA_sEPSC_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'minocycline' & Condition == "minocycline") %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::summarize(x = sd(median_DecayTau), count = n()) %>% dplyr::summarize(x/sqrt(count)), digits = 2)` ms, n = `r BLA_sEPSC_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'minocycline') %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::select(Cell) %>% n_distinct()`, N = `r BLA_sEPSC_final %>% dplyr::filter(Experiment == 'minocycline') %>% group_by(Filename) %>% mutate(animals = str_sub(Filename, start = 1, end = 5)) %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::select(animals) %>% n_distinct()`, `r CX3CL1_sEPSC_mino_BLA_stat_sEPSC_dt`)(Fig. \@ref(fig:CX3CL1BLAsEPSC)b1-b3).
Thus, these observations indicate that microglia may be a key contributors in the regulation of excitatory drive in the BLA.<!--jakoś inaczej napisać... microglia...? postsynaptic mechanisms?--><!-- Our findings overall highlight microglia and its receptor CX3CR1 as key contributors in regulation of social behavioral adaptation to chronic stress.-->

The findings presented here demonstrated that the CX3CL1-induced downregulation of principal cell's excitability was also associated with GABA~A~ and GABA~B~ receptors (see Fig.\@ref(fig:CX3CL1BLAexcitabilityfrak)).
This is in line with mounting evidence pointing to local interneurons as key regulators of pyramidal-like neurons' activity (see Introduction \@ref(BLA)).
Hence, the possible influence of CX3CL1 on the inhibitory transmission onto BLA PCs was next explored in *in vitro* slices.<!-- Next, We next explored the possible influence of harmine on the GABAergic transmission onto BA PNs. -->
Cells were clamped at 0 mV to record the spontaneous inhibitory postsynaptic currents (sIPSCs).<!-- Spontaneous inhibitory postsynaptic currents (sIPSCs) were recorded *via* whole-cell patch clamp recordings (held at −70 mV).  -->
The representative traces of sIPSCs in the absence (baseline) and presence of CX3CL1 (2 and 5nM) are shown in Fig.\@ref(fig:CX3CL1BLAsIPSC).
At 2nM, CX3CL1 was ineffective in changing any of the sIPSCs measured parameters (for details, see Appendix \@ref(CX3CL1sIPSCappendix)), whereas higher concentration (5nM) of CX3CL1 robustly<!--markedly--> reduced the GABAergic transmission onto principal cells in the BLA, by decreasing the median frequency from `r round(BLA_sIPSC_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'CX3CL1(5nM)' & Condition == "baseline") %>% ungroup() %>% summarize(mean(median_Frequency)), digits = 2)` `r knitr::asis_output("\U00B1")` `r round(BLA_sIPSC_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'CX3CL1(5nM)' & Condition == "baseline") %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::summarize(x = sd(median_Frequency), count = n()) %>% dplyr::summarize(x/sqrt(count)), digits = 3)` to `r round(BLA_sIPSC_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'CX3CL1(5nM)' & Condition == "CX3CL1") %>% ungroup() %>% summarize(mean(median_Frequency)), digits = 2)` `r knitr::asis_output("\U00B1")` `r round(BLA_sIPSC_final %>% filter(Experiment == digits = 3)` to `r round(BLA_sIPSC_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'CX3CL1(5nM)' & Condition == "CX3CL1") %>% ungroup() %>% summarize(mean(median_Amplitude)), digits = 2)` `r Further analysis of IPSCs kinetics showed that the median rise times and decay times<!--and mIPSCs--> remained unchanged (from `r round(BLA_sIPSC_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'CX3CL1(5nM)' & Condition == "baseline") %>% ungroup() %>% summarize(mean(median_RiseTime)), digits = 2)` `r knitr::asis_output("\U00B1")` `r round(BLA_sIPSC_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'CX3CL1(5nM)' & Condition == "baseline") %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::summarize(x = sd(median_RiseTime), count = n()) %>% dplyr::summarize(x/sqrt(count)), digits = 3)` to `r round(BLA_sIPSC_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'CX3CL1(5nM)' & Condition == "CX3CL1") %>% ungroup() %>% summarize(mean(median_RiseTime)), digits = 2)` `r knitr::asis_output("\U00B1")` `r round(BLA_sIPSC_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'CX3CL1(5nM)' & Condition == "CX3CL1") %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::summarize(x = sd(median_RiseTime), count = n()) %>% dplyr::summarize(x/sqrt(count)), digits = 3)` ms and from `r round(BLA_sIPSC_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'CX3CL1(5nM)' & Condition == "baseline") %>% ungroup() %>% summarize(mean(median_DecayTau)), digits = 2)` `r knitr::asis_output("\U00B1")` `r round(BLA_sIPSC_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'CX3CL1(5nM)' & Condition == "baseline") %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::summarize(x = sd(median_DecayTau), count = n()) %>% dplyr::summarize(x/sqrt(count)), digits = 3)` to `r round(BLA_sIPSC_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'CX3CL1(5nM)' & Condition == "CX3CL1") %>% ungroup() %>% summarize(mean(median_DecayTau)), digits = 2)` `r knitr::asis_output("\U00B1")` `r round(BLA_sIPSC_final %>% filter(Experiment == 'CX3CL1(5nM)' & Condition == "CX3CL1") %>% ungroup() %>% dplyr::summarize(x = sd(median_DecayTau), count = n()) %>% dplyr::summarize(x/sqrt(count)), digits = 3)` ms, respectively), as reported by data in Fig. \@ref(fig:CX3CL1BLAsIPSCappendixfig) in Appendix \@ref(CX3CL1sIPSCappendix).<!-- Data reported in Figure 1A confirms that-->

These findings indicates a functional involvement of CX3CR1 and microglia in the modulation of BLA GABAergic transmission (Fig.\@ref(fig:CX3CL1BLAsIPSC)).<!-- suggesting a functional involvement of CCR2 in the modulation of spinal GABAergic transmission. lepsze słowo? // These effects were blocked in the presence of minocycline and minocycline, suggesting its dependency of CX3CR1- and microglia. -->

In parallel with this, the cumulative probability curve of sIPSC amplitude was considerably right-shifted (p = 0.0028, Kolmogorov–Smirnov test,supplemental, Fig. S2D). 
The cumulative probability curve of interevent interval, on the other hand, was left-shifted upon harmine treatment (p < 0.0001, Kolmogorov– Smirnov test, supplemental, Fig.S2E).  zmienić -->


In addition, to determine if a decrease in sIPSC frequency by CX3CL1 was due to a change in the spontaneous action potential firing in the slice, the TTX (500nM) was used to block neuronal firing.
The mIPSC amplitude, frequency, and kinetics were measured before and after the CX3CL1 application (clamped at 0 mV).<!-- Alternatively: To determine whether there was a direct effect of CX3CL1 on GABAergic terminals, miniature mIPSC (mIPSCs) were recorded from principal cells. In these experiments TTX was used to block the action potentials. -->
No changes in these parameters were found between baseline and CX3CL1-applied recordings (see Fig.\@ref(fig:CX3CL1BLAsIPSC)b and c, mIPSC frequency: `r CX3CL1_ttx_BLA_stat_sIPSC_freq`, mIPSC amplitude: `r CX3CL1_ttx_BLA_stat_sIPSC_amp`).
<!-- The mIPSC frequency data may be consistent with the paired-pulse data and suggests that D3Rs reduce GABA release at the local synapses. However, the mIPSC amplitude data, along with the absence of any effect on PPRs at the LPC synapses, suggests that D3Rs may also modulate local and LPC synapses via a postsynaptic mechanism as well. -->
Hence, data presented here suggest that CX3CL1 reduces GABA release at the local BLA synapses, probably by depression of the spontaneous firing of local interneurons.<!-- przemyśleć to jeszcze-->
Notably, the decreased median amplitude of sIPSCs<!-- , along with the absence of any effect on PPRs at the LPC synapses,--> suggests that this signaling molecule might also modulate synapses *via* a postsynaptic mechanism. 
Moreover, this inhibition of GABAergic transmission by 5nM CX3CL1 was mediated by both CX3CR1 and microglia.

### CX3CL1 impairs the long-term potentiation in the BLA


Considering studies indicating CX3CL1 involvement in memory, along with presented here depression of glutamatergic neurons in the BLA, the next step was to gain insights into how CX3CL1 modulates the BLA network activity.
To this end, the extracellular recordings were employed.
The amplitude of field potentials as well as short-term plasticity and long-term potentiation were assessed.<!-- paired pulse ratio // LTP, which is closely related to memory formation and is predominately regulated by the glutamatergic system,  -->
At the beginning of each experiment, the I/O curves were determined, as shown in Figure \@ref(fig:CX3CL1BLALTP)a. 
No significant differences were evident between the input–output curves of FPs recorded from the control and CX3CL1-induced slices (<!--number of slices = uzupełnić-->F (3, 41) = 0.4,	P=0.75, ANOVA)<!--jaka? mixed? two-way?-->, indicating that CX3CL1 did not modulate the baseline excitatory activity in the BLA under our experimental conditions.<!-- może jeszcze lepiej to napisać?-->
The paired-pulse ratio, a form of short-term plasticity sensitive mainly to presynaptic changes [@stuart_1991], was also investigated.
<!-- jedno zdanie że external capsule input stimulation led to PPF in all experiments -->
This parameter also remained unaffected by CX3CL1 treatment (<!--number of slices = uzupełnić,-->H= 3.930, p = 0.27, Kruskal-Wallis test; see Fig. \@ref(fig:CX3CL1BLALTP)b), suggesting that CX3CL1 action in the BLA is rather not presynaptic.<!-- może też trochę lepiej napisać?--><!-- wcześniej: Comparing control and CX3CL1-applied slices, no significant effect on the basal excitability, as assessed by input – output curves, was found as well as the paired-pulse ratio remained unaffected by this manipulation (see Fig. \@ref(fig:CX3CL1BLALTP), parts a and b). -->
<!-- jakieś ogólne zdanie o LTP? Two tetanic stimuli applied at 100 Hz to fibers running through the external capsule produced robust LA-LTP both in TPH2+/+and TPH2− / −mice. // TBS applied to the Schaffer collateral-CA1 pathway was also effective at inducing LTP both in TPH2+/+and TPH2− / −mice.-->
Notably, upon application of TBS<!--Theta Burst Stimulation-->, external capsule-evoked field potentials in the BLA were effectively potentiated in the control slices, but not in the slices treated with CX3CL1, as revealed by a significant decrease measured by the comparison of average potentiation before and after LTP induction (F(2, 26) = 156.6, p < 0.001, ANOVA and Tukey's post hoc test<!--jaka?-->; see Fig.\@ref(fig:CX3CL1BLALTP)c).<!-- moja statystyka do zrobienia... albo Bartkowa...(Figure 4g, t (16) = 4.03, P = 0.001)--><!-- poprawić mixed model repeated-measure ANOVA (group effect: (F (1,16) = 16.27, P = 0.001; and group × post-HFS time point interaction: F(2.071,33.136) = 9.231, P = 0.001, Greenhouse – Geisser correction; Figure 4f)// The comparison of average potentiation across time points after induction also revealed a highly significant difference between these two groups of slices (Figure 4g, t (16) = 4.03, P = 0.001).// Upon application of HFS, vSub-evoked field potentials in the BLA were effectively potentiated in the control group, but not in the NF knockdown group as revealed by mixed model  repeated-measure  ANOVA  (group  effect:  (F (1,16) = 16.27, P = 0.001; and group × post-HFS time point interaction: F(2.071,33.136) = 9.231, P = 0.001, Greenhouse – Geisser correction; Figure 4f). The comparison of average potentiation across time points after induction-->
However, the additional presence of AZD8797, CX3CR1 antagonist, did not fully abolish this effect (F(2, 26) = 156.6, p < 0.001, ANOVA and Tukey's post hoc test).
Together, these findings demonstrate an <!--specific--> impairment of BLA synaptic plasticity to external capsule inputs after CX3CL1 treatment.<!-- of external capsule inputs to LA/BLA.-->
Considering that one of the mechanisms of synaptic plasticity is changes in dendritic spines morphology<!--inaczej to napisać-->, the next goal was to examine whether CX3CL1 affects dendrites morphology in the amygdala.

<!--The observed in this study reduced PCs' excitability, together with a decrease in GABAergic drive, was ...
As many reports indicated the effect of CX3CL1 on the LTP citations , together with accumulating evidence concerning the relevance of interneurons in this process in the BLA  citations , ...  dokończyć--><!--We assessed long-term potentiation (LTP) in the ventral external capsule– BLA pathway, which represents the major connection between cortex and BLA. -->

### CX3CL1 changes the length/head width ratio of dendritic spines in cultured rat amygdala neurons

To confirm whether CX3CL1-induced impairment in the LTP is accompanied by changes in dendritic morphology, the shape of dendritic spines was analyzed.<!--In addition, we also examined spine morphology because changes in spine morphology are believed to represent one mechanism by which synaptic activity leaves its imprint on neurons. // To confirm whether dendritic spine density was increased, // To analyze <the afferent connectivity of fully mature newborn granule neurons, we examined the dendritic spines of 8-weekold RFP+ cells.-->
To this end, the primary neuronal cultures were prepared from amygdala of rat pups at P0.<!-- To confirm whether dendritic spine density was increased,-->
It should be noted that the action of CX3CL1 is not mediated by microglia, as used cultures were deprived of those glial cells.
<!-- arac? -->

Dendritic spines can be classified into into mushroom, thin, or stubby types on the basis of morphological criteria (Pallas-Bazarra et al., 2016; Pallas-Bazarra et al., 2017).<!--dać publikacje zespołu Jakuba--><!-- znaleźć publikacje: These spines can be classified into various typologies on the basis of morphological criteria (Pallas-Bazarra et al., 2016; Pallas-Bazarra et al., 2017).// In addition, the classification of dendritic spines into mushroom, thin and stubby types is illustrated. -->
Neurons <!--of CX3CR1?/? mice--> showed a reduction in the total number of dendritic spines.
To further characterize the populations of spines present in these cells, we measured the percentage of each type of spine (D).

Fig. \@ref(fig:spines) shows representative images of dendritic fragments of cultured neurons during baseline (a) and after 20 minutes of CX3CL1 application (b).<!--poprawić??--><!--newborn neurons of WT (A) and CX3CR1?/? (B) animals -->
Dendrites of these neurons always exhibited a high density of spines ( Fig. 2 A), typical of BL projection neurons [@mcdonald_2005].<!-- Dendrites of these neurons always exhibited a high density of spines ( Fig. 2 A), typical of BL projection neurons [21,35,43,50] MCDONALD 2005, ZMIENIĆ...-->

As shown, the percentage of stubby spines was increased in CX3CR1?/? animals, whereas that of mushroom spines was reduced. 
Thus, these data show that the CX3CL1 application led to an alterations in their morphology (namely, an enlargement and shortening of the head).<!-- zmienić // Thus, these data show that the absence of CX3CR1 leads to a decrease in the number of newborn granule neuron dendritic spines and alterations in their morphology (namely, an enlargement and shortening).-->
<!-- In addition, we also examined spine morphology because changes in spine morphology are believed to represent one mechanism by which synaptic activity leaves its imprint on neurons. This was concurrent with an increase in spines with well-defined heads, which is correlated with spine maturation.-->

Therefore, accompanying these electrophysiological ..... was the immature morphological phenotype of dendritic spines.<!--Accompanying this delay in maturation of spine density was a defect in functional maturation of hippocampal synapses as measured by the ratio of spontaneous and miniature excitatory postsynaptic current amplitude (sEPSC/mEPSC amplitude ratio), long-term depression induction, and seizure susceptibility.-->
Notably, these alternations are independent of microglia.
<!-- his review discusses spine alterations in animal models of maternal immune activation in the context of neurodevelopmental disorders-->

### CX3CL1 and CX3CR1 are expressed in principal cells in the basolateral nucleus of the amygdala

Calcium/calmodulin-dependent protein kinase II (CaMK) has been shown to play a critical role in long-term potentiation (LTP) and emotional learning mediated by the basolateral amygdala.<!--citation?-->
This is also a critical marker of principal cells in the BLA [@mcdonald_2002a].
As results presented in this dissertation show that CX3CL1 induced a depression of principal cell's excitability and the impairment in LTP in the BLA, the immunohistochemistry used to examine the level of the expression of CX3CL1 and CX3CR1 in CAMK-II-`r knitr::asis_output("\U03B1")`-positive cells in the BLA.<!--little is known about its cellular localization in this region. We have utilized immunohistochemical methods to study the neuronal localization of CaMK, and its relationship to -aminobutyric acid (GABA)-ergic structures, in the rat basolateral amygdala (ABL). Light microscopic observations revealed dense CaMK staining in the ABL. analogous --><!--To define what types of cells in the brain express CX3CL1 and its receptor, CX3CR1, in the BLA, immunohistochemical staining was performed for NeuN, GFAP, and CD31-->
As illustrated in Figure \@ref(fig:BLA_CX3CL1_immuno), around <!---->% of CAMK-II-positive cells also expressed CX3CL1, while CX3CR1 receptors were present in <!----->% of pyramidal-like neurons in the BLA.
The results regarding CX3CR1 expression in neurons, especially principal cells, were also confirmed in neuronal cultures of amygdala.
Hence, although all of the electrophysiological effects of the CX3CL1 were prevented by minocycline, the direct action of this chemokine on neurons is also plausible.
